textPrologue_Prologue.Message01: Navigation Officer:  Captain we can't see anything in fifty kilometer.
text.test2: This is some other test text 2
text.test3: This is some more other test text 3

q1.q: What should you do to manage a burn if burn gel is inaccessible?
q1.c: Leave the burn area open if transport is less than 2 hours.
q1.d: Leave the burn area open if transport is less than 1 hour.

q2.q: A 23 year old male presents with obvious distress and dyspnea, unilateral chest movement, and decreased SpO2 at 87% following a suspected blast injury from a pipe bomb. He is speaking in one to two word sentences. What should you do?

q3.q: A casualty has been shot in the face. He is conscious, sitting up, leaning forward, and maintaining his own airway. What should you do?
q3.a: Perform a surgical airway using a cricothyrotomy kit.
q3.b: Place him in the supine position and insert a nasopharyngeal airway.
q3.c: Apply a cervical collar to stabilize the spine.
q3.d: Allow him to continue to sit up and lean forward as care is rendered.

q4.q: A 37 year old hostage exits a house and begins seizing. He has stopped seizing by the time you extract him. He is breathing at 24 breaths per minute with adequate chest rise and fall but he is still unresponsive. What should you do?
q4.a: Sit the patient up against a tree.
q4.b: Roll him into a prone position.
q4.d: Place him in the recovery position.

q5.q: In the indirect threat care/warm zone, you have just finished your MARCH algorithm and patient assessment on your wounded partner. As you are preparing for evacuation, you notice the patient is cold. What should you do?

q6.q: A 29 year old male has a single gunshot wound to the pelvis. A junctional tourniquet was placed and appears to be effective. He is pale, has a weak radial pulse, and is screaming in pain. You have decided to provide pain management via IV/IO. What should you administer?

q7.q: Which of the following is true of IV fluid administration?
q7.a: It should be administered over PO fluids.
q7.b: 1 liter should be administered via large gauge catheter run wide open TKO.
q7.c: It should be administered only when necessary to maintain a systolic BP of 80 to 90 mm Hg.
q7.d: It should be administered to all casualties with traumatic injuries.

q8.q: Law enforcement officers are called to the scene of a barricaded suspect. After securing the perimeter, officers watch the house for signs of movement. Suddenly, the suspect begins shooting with a rifle from his front window, and an officer is shot in the neck. He yells, “I’m hit!” What should you do?
q8.a: Wait for help from other officers.
q8.b: Stop the bleeding with direct pressure.
q8.c: Move off the X to cover.
q8.d: Stop the bleeding with a hemostatic dressing.

q9.q: A 34 year old officer was shot in the ankle and a tourniquet was applied. He is unresponsive after several doses of IM morphine. Vital signs are BP 118/68, P 104, R 8 and shallow. What should you administer?

q10.q: A 28 year old officer was struck in the head while entering a hostile environment. Upon assessment, you note that he has an irregular respiratory pattern, elevated blood pressure, and a decreased pulse. At what level should you maintain this patient’s capnography?

q11.q: The intervention of placing a nasopharyngeal airway in a casualty is best accomplished through the use of which of the following?

q12.q: After placing an occlusive dressing over a large-caliber gunshot wound to the chest, your patient begins to experience increasing shortness of breath, anxiety, and tachycardia. What should you do?
q12.a: Re-secure the occlusive dressing on four sides using medical tape.
q12.b: Place a second occlusive dressing over the first.
q12.c: Place a 14-gauge × 3.25-inch needle in the chest at the 3rd ICS at the sternal border.

q13.q: A police officer suffered blunt trauma to her abdomen after multiple handgun rounds struck her body armor without penetration. She has diffuse abdominal pain and bruising. She is awake, capable, and wants to help with casualty collection point security. How should you implement fluid resuscitation?
q13.a: Encourage her to drink fluids and self-hydrate.
q13.b: Establish humeral head IO access for aggressive fluid resuscitation.
q13.c: Place a 14-gauge IV catheter and pressure infuse 20 ml/kg of crystalloid solution × 2 doses.
q13.d: Begin a whole blood transfusion from one of the other law enforcement officers.

q14.q: A 36 year old male was a casualty during an explosion at a bank. He is responsive with burns to at least 20% of his total body surface area. His clothing is still smoldering. What should you do first?
q14.a: Wrap burn injuries in dry sterile dressings.

q15.q: During an armored car robbery, a 37 year old male security guard was shot by the perpetrator and fell from his armored car. He suffered a penetrating wound to the left thigh with spurting blood and a fractured right wrist. What should you do?
q15.a: Utilize pressure point to stop the bleeding.
q15.b: Apply a tourniquet to the left thigh.

q16.q: Immediately after being shot during an active shooter situation, a responder is bleeding heavily from the right lower forearm. The second responder advises him to apply direct pressure to the wound and to self-evacuate behind a nearby vehicle. Which phase of care does this scenario illustrate?

q17.q: What effect does morphine have on the cardiovascular system?

q18.q: What size catheter should you use for needle decompression on an adult?

q19.q: A 33 year old responder is bleeding heavily from a gunshot wound to the right chest. He complains of difficulty breathing and pain to the injured site. An active shooter is in the vicinity and you are in the warm zone. What should you do?
q19.b: Perform needle decompression, midclavicular, between the 2nd and 3rd intercostal space.
q19.d: Apply a gloved hand over the injury then apply an occlusive dressing.

q20.q: A 26 year old female has multiple puncture wounds to the thoracic cavity. Vital signs are BP 160/100, P 100 and regular, R 30 short and shallow, SpO2 94% on room air. What should you do?
q20.a: Establish IV/IO access and deliver 1,000 ml of fresh whole blood.
q20.b: Apply high-flow oxygen with a nonrebreathing mask.
q20.c: Apply vented chest seal to appropriate areas
q20.d: Give her a paper bag to help regulate her breathing back to normal.

q21.q: A 16 year old male is found at the base of the steps during a mass shooting incident. The patient presents with altered mental status and blood leaking from his ears. What should you suspect?

q22.q: A 45 year old male at the casualty collection point has multiple gunshot wounds to his lower extremities. A police officer has applied tourniquets prior to your arrival. He is slow to respond and mumbles his words. His radial pulse is weak. What should you do?

q23.q: A 25 year old male has a gunshot wound to the left leg. A tourniquet was applied to control bleeding and he is managing his airway. In the casualty collection point, he is anxious with a weak radial pulse and is shivering. What should you do?
q23.b: Remove wet clothing, and apply a thermal barrier.
q23.c: Initiate skin to skin contact warming.
q23.d: Administer warmed blood product with a Ready Heat Blanket.

q24.q: A 17 year old male was a victim of a blast injury. He is unconscious and moaning. He has multiple superficial lacerations along with a scalp laceration. What is an ideal systolic blood pressure to maintain for this patient?

q25.q: You are the tactical medic for a SWAT team that is entering a building where an improvised explosive device (IED) has detonated. During the indirect threat phase, you encounter a male patient who is unconscious and lying on his back. The patient has obvious facial trauma and snoring respirations. What should you do first?
q25.a: Place the patient in the recovery position.
q25.b: Sit the patient up and move to the next patient.

q26.q: Prior to placing a casualty on a litter for evacuation, you observe significant swelling to the patient's left upper arm. Upon further examination, it is apparent that capillary refill is delayed, the extremity is cool to the touch, and the radial pulse is weak. What should you suspect?

q27.q: During direct threat care, in which instance should you utilize rapid application of a tourniquet?
q27.a: A patient with a gunshot wound to the posterior left shoulder that is heavily bleeding
q27.b: An unconscious patient with a graze wound on his right upper arm that is lightly bleeding
q27.c: A small child with a gunshot wound through his right hand that is minimally bleeding
q27.d: A patient with a gunshot wound to her left thigh that has soaked through her clothing

q28.q: A 38 year old female has lost approximately 1 liter of blood due to a gunshot wound to the upper thigh. The bleeding is controlled with a tourniquet, and the patient is pale, cool, and clammy. What type of shock should you suspect?

q29.q: A 39 year old female casualty is bleeding from a junctional wound. What should you do?
q29.a: Apply a CAT tourniquet to the injured area.
q29.b: Reposition the casualty to elevate the injured area.
q29.c: Pack the wound with a hemostatic dressing.
q29.d: Administer 1 gram of TXA via IV infusion.

q30.q: You have treated a casualty for a sucking chest wound by applying a nonvented occlusive dressing. As you continue to monitor the casualty, you notice an increase in difficulty breathing. What should you do?

q31.q: Which parameters are appropriate for adult needle decompression and are documented to have a high success rate, especially in patients with higher body mass index (BMI)?
q31.a: Second intercostal space, midclavicular line, 14-gauge, 1.25 needle
q31.b: Second intercostal space, midaxillary line, 14-gauge, 3.25 needle
q31.c: Fifth intercostal space, anterior axillary line, 14-gauge, 3.25 needle
q31.d: Fifth intercostal space, midaxillary line, 14-gauge, 1.25 needle

q32.q: A 27 year old male that was involved in an explosive event is brought to you for treatment. His airway is patent and high-flow oxygen has been administered. He has suffered full-thickness burns over approximately 40% of his body. Vital signs are BP 92/70, P 124, R 22. What should you do?
q32.a: Obtain IV/IO access and begin fluid resuscitation.
q32.b: Begin ventilations with a bag-mask device.
q32.d: Initiate rapid transport to a specialized burn center.

q33.q: Why should hemostatic dressings be avoided during direct threat care?
q33.a: They take up too much space.
q33.b: Time constraints make the procedure unsafe.
q33.c: Assuring a patent airway is a greater priority than hemorrhage control in the hot zone.
q33.d: A tourniquet can control any life-threatening bleeding.

q34.q: A 25 year old male is short of breath following the deployment of a flash-bang device that caused a fire inside an apartment. He is breathing rapidly, audibly wheezing, and has soot around his lips. Vital signs are BP 140/90, P 120, R 36 and labored. What should you suspect?

q35.q: A 29 year old bystander has a gunshot wound to the upper right leg. A tourniquet was applied prior to arrival at the treatment area. He complains of severe leg pain. Vital signs are BP 110/50, P 100, R 24. What should you do?
q35.a: Continue to monitor casualty and move on to the next patient.
q35.b: Reassess tourniquet effectiveness and administer 50 mg of ketamine IM.
q35.c: Administer 2 Tylenol 650 mg bilayer caplets PO and Meloxicam 15 mg PO.
q35.d: Initiate an IV of normal saline and administer a 500 mL fluid bolus.

q36.q: A 23 year old male suffered an isolated penetrating eye injury prior to evacuation from the scene. What should you do in order to safely transport the patient?
q36.a: Tightly wrap pressure patches around both eyes.
q36.c: Cover the eye with a rigid eye shield.
q36.d: Put safety goggles on the patient.

q37.q: A 30-year-old female with a calculated total body surface area burn of 60% presents with hypotension. When should fluid resuscitation be initiated?
q37.b: As soon as IV/IO is established

q38.q: Which patient requires the application of a tourniquet?
q38.a: 23 year old male with a penetrating wound to the upper right chest; agonal respirations
q38.b: 35 year old male with a gunshot wound to the right arm; bright red blood spurting from the wound
q38.c: 18 year old female with an open fracture to her wrist; dark blood oozing from the fracture area
q38.d: 46 year old male motorcyclist with a closed femur fracture to the left leg; swelling and deformity to the thigh

q39.q: A 24 year old male police officer has a gunshot wound to right upper thigh with profuse bleeding. After application of a tourniquet, the bleeding is controlled. His skin is clammy and he has weak radial pulses with a respiratory rate of 28. He complains of severe pain from the tourniquet. What should you administer to manage the pain?
q39.a: Oral transmucosal fentanyl lozenge at 800 mcg

q40.q: What is the most common initial presentation for a tension pneumothorax after chest trauma?

q41.q: When should foreign bodies be removed from the eye?
q41.a: During the indirect threat care phase
q41.b: During the direct threat care phase
q41.d: Anytime there is a free moment

q42.q: After a mass-casualty incident, you are retriaging injuries. A 35 year old male with a gunshot wound to the upper right chest who was previously treated with a nonvented occlusive dressing is currently very anxious and complaining of difficulty breathing. What should you do?

q43.q: Your RTF team is taking care of a casualty who has extensive facial trauma secondary to a gunshot wound. She is conscious and there is no suspected spinal injury. Your casualty complains of being uncomfortable, and she is attempting to sit up. What should you do?
q43.b: Administer fentanyl IO to sedate her and manage pain.
q43.c: Allow her to sit up and lean forward as it may help open her airway.
q43.d: Instruct her to remain supine because it is better for her.

q44.q: Why is a properly inserted nasopharyngeal airway an effective method of maintaining an airway?
q44.a: It enables you to suction the airway.
q44.b: It can be used as a definitive airway.
q44.c: It prevents the patient from speaking and interrupting your assessment.
q44.d: It prevents the tongue from sliding back and blocking the airway.

q45.q: A 35 year old male has suffered second-degree burns to his chest, arms, and face. He has singed facial hair and is complaining of severe pain and shortness of breath. His voice is raspy and you note audible stridor. Vital signs are BP 150/80, P 130, R 32 and shallow. What should you do?
q45.a: Obtain the patient’s room air SpO2.
q45.c: Administer high-flow oxygen via nonrebreathing mask.
q45.d: Establish IV access and begin fluid resuscitation.

q46.q: When preparing to move a casualty during the direct threat care phase, which factor(s) should you identify?
q46.b: How many people are needed, where you are moving to, and how you are moving the casualty
q46.c: What injuries the casualty has sustained and the need for spinal immobilization
q46.d: The triage designation of the casualty

q47.q: In which location should a tourniquet or pressure bandage work?

q48.q: After the scene of an explosion has been declared safe, you find a 19 year old male with 40% total body surface area burns with no visible signs of hemorrhage. His pulse is weak and he is only responsive to painful stimuli. What should you administer?

q49.q: Which patient should be first for transport from the casualty collection point?
q49.a: Penetrating wound to the abdomen; unresponsive with absent radial pulses
q49.b: Tension pneumothorax relieved by needle decompression
q49.c: Massive hemorrhage of the right arm controlled by a tourniquet
q49.d: Unresponsive; penetrating wound to the head and exposed brain matter

q50.q: What is a sign that your patient has a thoracic injury?
q50.a: Increased breath sound on the right side
q50.d: Crepitus to the left side of the chest wall

q51.q: Which of the following is not a principle of TECC?
q51.d: Develop a mission specific medical plan

q52.q: Which of the following is NOT one of the three phases of care in TECC?

q53.q: Which of the following is the preferred pain medication for someone who has wounds that are moderately painful but not life-threatening and that do not keep a patient from functioning effectively as a combatant?

q54.q: The most common cause of preventable death in a tactical situation is which of the following?
q54.a: Failure to use a tourniquet to control severe extremity bleeding.
q54.b: Failure to maintain an open airway.
q54.c: Not establishing an IV soon enough.

q55.q: Which of the following are the best field indicators of shock during Indirect Threat Care?
q55.b: Level of consciousness and quality of the radial pulse

q56.q: Administering large quantities of IV crystalloids to a casualty who has bleeding sites inside the chest or abdomen may worsen hemorrhage by which of the following mechanisms?
q56.a: Diluting clotting factors or by interfering with clot formation at the bleeding site.
q56.d: By increasing the vascular wall permeability.

q57.q: A orpharyngeal airway (OPA) is contraindicated under which circumstances?
q57.b: Victim that has sustained Head and Facial trauma

q58.q: Which of the following conditions is most likely to worsen the outcome from TBI?

q59.q: What is the most appropriate next step to maintain an open airway after the chin- lift/jaw-thrust method has been used to successfully open the airway of a casualty who is unconscious from a blast injury during the Indirect Threat Care phase of care?

q60.q: As a Tactical Medic/EMT you are confronted with the following casualties. Which one should be cared for first?
q60.a: Casualty A – shot in the head and unconscious
q60.b: Casualty B – shot in the abdomen – awake and alert
q60.c: Casualty C – heavy bleeding from a thigh wound

q61.q: A casualty has sustained a gunshot wound to the chest. As you watch him, he is having more and more trouble with his breathing. What is the best next step?

q62.q: A casualty has sustained a gunshot wound to the face. He is conscious and maintaining his airway by sitting up and leaning forward. A Medic/EMT arrives on the scene. How should the casualty’s airway be managed?
q62.a: Place him in the supine position and intubate him
q62.b: Allow him to continue to sit up and lean forward

q63.q: What is the best quick-check method to determine if the patient has an adequate airway?
q63.a: Ask a question that requires a response from the casualty
q63.b: Check for a bluish color of the nail beds

q64.q: Which of the following is an acceptable site for needle decompression?
q64.a: 4th or 5th intercostal space at the anterior axillary line
q64.b: 1st or 2nd intercostal space at the anterior axillary line
q64.c: 2nd or 3rd intercostal space at the sternal border
q64.d: Just lateral of the Angle of Louis

q65.q: What level of blood loss is likely to be associated with death from hemorrhagic shock?

q66.q: Giving a rapid infusion of IV fluids to casualties may have a negative impact on outcome with the exception of which of the following conditions?

q67.q: Which of the following casualties has the greatest need for an emergent evacuation?
q67.a: A casualty of an IED who has a traumatic amputation of the leg at the knee with bleeding controlled by a tourniquet.
q67.b: A casualty who was shot in the head and is unconscious with a significant amount of brain tissue exposed.
q67.c: A casualty who was shot in the abdomen and now has an absent radial pulse.
q67.d: A casualty in traumatic cardiac arrest

q68.q: What is the most important thing to do after splinting an open fracture?
q68.a: Check to ensure that the pulses distal to the splint have not been reduced by the splint
q68.b: Check to ensure that the extremity is completely covered by the wrapping material used in splinting
q68.c: Check to ensure that the extremity is in perfect alignment
q68.d: Check the remaining extremities for fractures

q69.q: Which of the following is an appropriate reason to give casualty morphine?
q69.a: His wounds are minor and he can continue to fight
q69.c: He has a chest wound and is in respiratory distress

q70.q: Which of the following statements about Tactical Casualty Care is true?
q70.a: Extremity hemorrhage is the most frequent cause of preventable deaths in the tactical situation.
q70.b: Most tactical fatalities die from airway problems
q70.c: Life-threatening extremity bleeding is treated in the Direct Threat Care phase with Hemostatic Gauze
q70.d: Airway management is accomplished in the Direct Threat Care phase

q71.q: You are treating a casualty with a gunshot wound to his lower jaw which severely disrupts the oropharyngeal anatomy.  He suddenly develops complete airway obstruction, struggles briefly, and loses consciousness. What is the airway intervention of choice?

q72.q: During an early morning high risk warrant service in a rural area you sustained a gunshot wound to your right thigh that produced heavy arterial bleeding. You initially controlled the hemorrhage by applying your own tourniquet. There are no other medics in your unit, and the helicopter evacuation platform will arrive at your location in one-half hour. The closest trauma center is 15 minutes away by air. Which is the best strategy for dealing with the tourniquet on your leg?
q72.a: Replace the tourniquet with a Hemostatic Gauze dressing
q72.b: Loosen the tourniquet to see if the bleeding stopped
q72.c: Construct a pressure dressing over your leg wound, and remove the tourniquet yourself

q73.q: Which of the following statements concerning Tactical Casualty Care is true?
q73.a: Casualties who are alert and can swallow should not be allowed to take fluids by mouth.
q73.b: The intraosseous method is a good way to obtain vascular access for a casualty in whom an IV cannot be started.
q73.c: Pulse oximetry and other electronic monitoring are not useful during helicopter Tactical Evacuation Care.
q73.d: All combat wounds produce severe pain.

q74.q: Fluid resuscitation to treat shock is first considered in which phase of care?

q75.q: Which statement concerning hypothermia is true?
q75.a: Much easier to prevent than treat
q75.b: Not an issue in modern military or civilian helicopters
q75.d: Impossible to prevent in all casualties

q76.q: All of the following are an advantage of fentanyl lozenges over morphine except which one?
q76.a: No need to start an IV to administer

q77.q: Which of the following describes the correct landmarks for performing a needle decompression (on the side of the chest with the injury)?

q78.q: In a hazardous environment, what is the initial treatment of choice for stopping severe extremity hemorrhage?

q79.q: What is the primary role for Hemostatic Gauze dressings?
q79.b: Abdominal wounds without severe external bleeding
q79.c: Open head wounds with minor bleeding and brain matter exposed

q80.q: You have a casualty with severe external bleeding from a groin wound. During Indirect Threat Care, you packed the wound with hemostatic gauze but were unsuccessful at stopping the hemorrhage. What should you do next?
q80.a: Stop and take a few minutes to think about what to do next.
q80.b: Revert to a standard gauze dressing to control bleeding.
q80.c: Remove the first hemostatic gauze and replace with a second.
q80.d: Stick your finger into the wound and block the bleeding blood vessel

q81.q: A casualty with a decreased level of consciousness (without TBI) and an abnormal radial pulse is considered as which of the following?

q82.q: Which is the best route for administering morphine to a trauma patient?

q83.q: In addition to treating the casualty and completing the mission, what is the third objective of TECC?
q83.a: Stop tactical movement to arrange medical care
q83.b: Evacuate all casualties via Helicopter EMS
q83.c: Prevent additional injuries and minimize public harm

q84.q: A casualty with a sucking chest wound has been treated with an non-vented occlusive dressing. She begins to have increasing difficulty breathing. Which of the following is the correct first action?
q84.b: Lift one side of the occlusive dressing
q84.d: increase the amount of oxygen administered

q85.q: Positive pressure ventilation and the use of an unvented chest seal may predispose a patient to which of the following complications?

q86.q: Which of the following is the preferred IV/IM antibiotic in TECC?

q87.q: How should tourniquets be applied in Direct Threat Care?
q87.b: Loose to be tightened later if all other attempts at bleeding control fail
q87.c: Exactly 1.5 to 2 inches above the injury with no clothing between the tourniquet and the casualty’s skin

q88.q: Before giving narcotic analgesia to a combatant, the provider should first take which of the following actions?
q88.c: Ask permission from the combatant’s physician
q88.d: Make sure the combatant is on an evacuation platform before receiving analgesia

q89.q: Why is ketamine useful in trauma?
q89.a: It has less of an effect on blood pressure than morphine or Fentanyl
q89.c: It is less of a vasoconstrictor
q89.d: The casualty can still fight after administration

q90.q: All of the following will make a TBI worse except which finding?

q91.q: Which statement about tourniquets is false?
q91.a: Damage to an arm or a leg is rare if the tourniquet is left on for less than two hours.
q91.b: Tourniquets are often left in place for several hours during surgical procedures.
q91.c: Training tourniquets can be used on missions if they have only been used for less than six months.
q91.d: All unit members should have a tourniquet at a standard location on their battle gear.

q92.q: Which of the following statements regarding TXA is false?
q92.b: It prevents the breakdown of forming clots.
q92.c: The survival benefit is greatest if it is given within one hour of injury.
q92.d: A second dose should be given after initial fluid resuscitation is completed.

q93.q: What should a provider do if a patient’s blood pressure drops while receiving TXA?
q93.b: Add an additional gram of TXA to the infusion

q94.q: The goals of fluid resuscitation are a palpable radial pulse and which of the following?
q94.c: End points defined by the Parkland formula
q94.d: Improved level of consciousness in the absence of a traumatic brain injury

q95.q: When dealing with pediatric casualties, which of the following may enhance airway positioning?
q95.d: Withholding Oxygen to promote a hypoxic drive

q96.a: Prevents clots that are forming from being broken down by the body
q96.b: Elevates ATP production resulting in increased energy
q96.c: Blocks the Krebs Cycle, thus decreasing acidosis

q97.q: Which of the following is a common site for junctional hemorrhage?

q98.q: What is the most appropriate type of catheter to use to decompress a tension pneumothorax?

q99.q: Which term describes air between the lung and chest wall due to an injury to the lung (either open or closed)?

q100.q: How long does it take to bleed to death from a complete femoral artery and vein disruption?
q100.b: Femoral artery injuries are extremely rare and are not a concern

q101.q: A 25-year-old male has a gunshot wound to the left leg. A tourniquet was applied to control bleeding, and he is maintaining an open airway. In the cold zone, he is anxious with a weak radial pulse and is shivering. What should you do?
q101.b: Remove wet clothing and apply a thermal barrier.
q101.c: Ask a paramedic to administer a warned IV infusion.
q101.d: Administer warmed blood products with a Ready-Heat blanket.

q102.q: While you are in the hot zone, a team member is hit in the helmet with shrapnel. His helmet has 2 cm of intrusion, but it effectively stopped the object. He is supine and unconscious. What should you do?
q102.a: Place the patient in the recovery position.
q102.b: Minimize environmental exposure and promote heat retention.
q102.c: Obtain IV access with an 18-gauge needle.

q103.q: A 33-year-old male has been shot by an assailant while shopping at the local mall. He is awake, seems confused, and keeps screaming, "I can't breathe!" He has a gunshot wound to his upper right chest that is bubbling as he breathes. His is pale, sweating, and in obvious respiratory distress. What should you do?

q104.q: Your SWAT team is entering a building where an improvised explosive device (IED) has detonated. During the indirect threat phase, you encounter a male patient who is unconscious and lying on his back. The patient has obvious facial trauma and snoring respirations. What should you do first?
q104.b: Place the patient in the recovery position.
q104.c: Sit the patient up and move to the next patient.

q105.q: Why is a nasopharyngeal airway an effective method of maintaining an airway?
q105.a: It prevents the patient from speaking and interrupting your assessment.
q105.b: The nasopharyngeal airway is more easily dislodged.
q105.c: The nasopharyngeal airway is better tolerated by a conscious patient.
q105.d: It can be used as a definitive airway.

q106.q: A 37-year-old hostage is in a house and begins seizing. He has stopped seizing by the time you extract him. He is breathing at 224 breaths per minute with adequate chest rise and fall, but he is still unresponsive. What should you do?
q106.a: Place him in the recovery position.
q106.b: Roll him into a prone position.
q106.d: Sit the patient up against a tree.

q107.q: During an armored car robbery, a 37-year-old male security guard was shot by the perpetrator and fell from his armored car. He suffered a penetrating wound to the left thigh with spurting blood and a fractured right wrist. What should you do first?
q107.b: Apply a tourniquet to the left thigh.
q107.c: Utilize pressure points to stop the bleeding.

q108.q: A 33-year-old responder is bleeding heavily from a gunshot wound to the right chest. He complains of difficulty breathing and pain to the injured site. An active shooter is in the vicinity. What should you do?
q108.d: Apply a gloved hand over the injury, and then apply an occlusive dressing.

q109.q: Your RFT team is taking care of a casualty who has extensive facial trauma secondary to a gunshot wound. She is conscious, and there is no suspected spinal injury. Your casualty complains of being uncomfortable, and she is attempting to sit up. What should you do?
q109.a: Instructor her to remain supine because it is better for her.
q109.b: Ask a paramedic to sedate her and manage pain.
q109.c: Establish cervical spine immobilization procedures regardless.
q109.d: Allow her to sit up and lean forward, because it may help open her airway.

q110.q: A 39-year-old female casualty is bleeding from a junctional wound. What should you do?
q110.a: Reposition the casualty to elevate the injured area.
q110.b: Pack the wound with a hemostatic dressing.
q110.c: Ask a paramedic to administer 1 gram of tranexamic acid via IV infusion.
q110.d: Apply a tourniquet to the injured area.

q111.q: Applying direct pressure to a wound is an appropriate intervention for which of the following casualties?
q111.a: Conscious victim with trickling bleeding during direct threat care
q111.b: Unconscious victim with minimal bleeding during indirect threat care
q111.c: Conscious victim with heavy bleeding during indirect threat care
q111.d: Conscious victim with heavy bleeding during direct threat care

q112.q: After a mass-casualty incident, you are retriaging injuries. A 35-year-old male with a gunshot wound to the upper right chest who was previously treated with a nonvented occlusive dressing is currently very anxious and complaining of difficulty breathing. What should you do?
q112.b: Place in a position of comfort.

q113.q: A 42-year-old female is lying prone on the floor after an improvised explosive device (IED) was detonated near her and several others. She is conscious, talking, and seems confused. You note minor bleeding from the mouth. What should you do?
q113.a: Place the patient in the recovery position.
q113.b: Sit the patient up, and move to the next patient.

q114.q: You have treated your partner for a sucking chest wound by applying a nonvented occlusive dressing. As you continue to monitor your partner, you notice she is having increased difficulty breathing. What should you do?

q115.q: A 16-year-old male is found at the base of the steps during a mass shooting incident. The patient presents with altered mental status and blood leaking form his ears. What should you suspect?

q116.q: In the indirect threat care/warm zone, you have finished your MARCH algorithm and patient assessment on your partner, who is wounded with a broken wrist. As you are preparing for evacuation, you notice your partner is cold. What should you do?
